Posts.Content: Hiya,  I had lumpectomy and sentinel lymp node removed, I had radioactive dye injected on the morning of my surgery. Cancer cells found in node so I had to go back for another opp more margin and node clearance. I didn't have the dye for second opp was told it wasn't needed, my operations were earlier this year.
Posts.Title: Radio active dye during lymph node removal

Posts.Content: This is a dilemma I've been having, due to start 6 rounds FEC-T any time just waiting for appointment to come through. My oncologist didn't even mention cold cap I had to ask, was told it would delay start of chemo as only so many caps available and success about 60%. The thought of loosing my hair has been very hard for me  I don't like much about myself but l love my hair, I've decided to embrace my baldness. My reasons are I don't want any treatment delayed we do enough waiting anyway and just want to get it done and my life back, I don't want to spend any more time at the hospital than necessary, I seem to spend my life there now, I'm not sure I'd tolerate it and no guarantee I will keep.my hair. We have a wedding to go to later in the year and my husband is already bald so maybe he will wear the wig and I will go bald for the wedding to make a change! X
Posts.Title: COLD CAP OR NO COLD CAP?

Posts.Content: Hiya, I've been suffering with my head becoming very flushed and hot, I got a chillow pillow which has been  a great help to me. Hope this helps X
Posts.Title: Remedies for chemo induced hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hi, I am Her2+ hormone-, I had Fec-T chemo last year and I'm still having the herceptin until June. I can only share my experience with suggestions that may make life easier for you. I had 3 Fec followed by 3 T. I didn't start the herceptin until I started the T part of the chemo. You should be given steroids to take and anti sickness, I wasn't given mine until I turned up for the 1st chemo, if the anti sickness don't work for you then ask for a different sort. You should have an echocardiogram before the herceptin starts and one every 3 months until the herceptin is finished. I chose not to use the cold cap, this makes the session a lot longer and I didn't want that but I'm sure someone who used it can tell you what it's like.I took an i-pad to keep me occupied during chemo sessions. You will need a thermometer and to take your temperature daily, I also kept an overnight back packed in case I had a raised temperature and had to go to hospital. Some people sail through the chemo with little or no problems, some people have problems with one or the other or both, I have to be honest, I was unlucky and felt bad with both whereas my friends mum on same regime sailed through with no problems.  It is all very doable and before you know it your chemo will be finished. I don't know if you have a big c centre near you, I am lucky with that as my hospital is Norwich which has a big c centre on site, but a big c centre is well worth a visit, it was there they told me about free prescriptions for 5 years (I'm 48) they also have a look good feel better workshop which I found wonderful. Hope this helps you.  X
Posts.Title: Her2 and hormone receptor positive

Posts.Content: Hi Sleepy Mushroom My bc bit different from yours but I can tell you my experience with the lymph nodes. I had 1 node removed as precaution (needle biopsy was clear) when I had my lumpectomy, histology report came back as cancer in the node (thank god for the precaution). Went back for node clearance, all came back as clear. I was straight on with the excersises they are quite hard initially but important that you stick with it. 5 weeks post surgery I have almost normal movement back in my arm still bit sore at times but nothing to bad. I am back at work while I wait for chemo start date. I have a medical alert band on that arm now and I'm careful not to loft anything to heavy and I check my arm everyday to watch out for signs of lymphodema. Hope this helps. X
Posts.Title: Advice on Axillary Lymph Nodes Dissection / Lymph Nodes Removal

Posts.Content: Hi Kate71, I think it depends on your hospital, we asked about my husband being trained to do my picc line as it's a 40 mile round trip to the hospital for us, they wouldn't train him, my hospital don't like anyone other than the trained staff messing with the lines as they can be temperamental. Mine was temperamental but still worth having and a decision I've never regretted. X
Posts.Title: Her2 and hormone receptor positive

Posts.Content: Hi, I had a picc line fitted for my treatment, it made treatment easier, the downside was having to go to the hospital every week to have it flushed but I still think the line was worth it. I got a waterproof cover from a company called limbo to keep the line dry in the shower. X
Posts.Title: Her2 and hormone receptor positive

Posts.Content: Hi 4paws,  I took my dog for her vaccinations today, the vet said about the vaccines and anyone on chemo (I finished my chemo last Aug) the normal vaccine is NOT live but a lot of vets are also giving kennel cough vaccine as part of annual jabs, the kennel cough vaccine IS live and that's the one you need to avoid. This is the third and last time my dog gets the kennel cough done, its squirted up her nose and she gets very stressed by it, she never goes into kennels as my brother moves in and looks after when we go away so I will not be putting her through kennel cough vaccine again. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and my dog

Posts.Content: I've not been on here much recently due to own problems, treatment related not family.  I can't imagine how tough this must make things for you, I wish there was something practical I could do to help. All I can say is thinking about you and sending lots of love and hugs your way xxx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: I also had WLE, 11 nodes removed with 1 positive. I had 6 Fec-t chemo, 3xfec followed by 3xt, the herceptin doesn't usually start until you go onto the t part of the chemo. You should also have an echocardiogram before they start the herceptin. I had a picc line fitted,it made the chemo so much easier, if they offer you one personally I think it's worth it. I would also say get yourself a decent thermometer as you will need to take your temperature every day throughout the chemo, you will be more vulnerable to infection so thermometer is vital for early warning sign. I would also suggest a bag with stuff to keep you amused during the chemo books, tablets etc. As for work I worked reduced hours after the opp but when I started the chemo I didn't work at all, it depends on how you  feel with it, it affects us all differently,  not gonna lie for me the chemo was tough and I ended up with couple of infections, but I did it and I'm out the other side, my friends mum had exactly the same chemo and she sailed thro without any bother. Listen to your body and don't overdo things.
Posts.Title: Preparation for Chemo and herceptin

Posts.Content: *strong*
Posts.Title: Everything tastes so bad!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hello,  I'm afraid to say I don't find anything makes a difference tho others may have different answers. I tend to drink iced water purely because everything tastes horrible so why waste money on coffee squash etc just to throw it away, at least water is free. I tend to eat a lot of strong cheese and crackers tho not great on the waistline. Ginger biscuits, ginger beer and you can also get sweets called gingins which are string ginger flavour are ment to be good, I like ginger but found the strong flavour to much as I tend to get mouth ulcers. I hope this helps, we are all different so is just a case of finding what works for you. X
Posts.Title: Everything tastes so bad!!!!!

Posts.Content: I first went to drs in Dec after finding a lump refured to hospital, mammogram, scan, biopsy, told Jan 11th was breast cancer lumpectomy 1 lymph node removed histology showed cells in lymph and not clear enough margin back for more margin and nodes removed, all clear for cancer. Now waiting for chemo am having FEC-T, I don't even have a start date still waiting for appointment for picc line and chemo. I believe I'm coping with the cancer diagnosis fairly well the thing that's messing my head is the constant waiting all the time. It was hard in the beginning when waiting to find out dates for surgery results etc but never did I think it would still be the same 4 months on waiting for chemo to start I just want to get on with it and back on with my life. Rant over! Lol.
Posts.Title: Fed up, still waiting

Posts.Content: Just an update, went for wig fitting yesterday, very impressed with the wig, anyway when got home had a letter saying picc line going in on Saturday, so expecting letter about chemo any day now. Did speak with my bc nurse this morning about nerve pain she also said if nothing by Monday then ring her back or ring oncology. To be fair my team have been very good on the whole, I'm not a very patient person at the best of times and struggle the most with waiting. Love n hugs to all x
Posts.Title: Fed up, still waiting

Posts.Content: I had drain back in February, 3 days after opp was Godsons christening, I explained to district nurse that I didn't wish to miss it, they were great they changed the bottle day before and was left that I would see them day after christening unless I had a problem. So off I went to the christening drain and all, I carried a shoulder bag with my drain in, family and friends made sure I was well looked after, my only issue was holding my godson. Was very tired by end but so pleased I'd been able to make it.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Blimey Jan that's dreadful, at least I've had 2 surgeries. I understand the meltdown, we think we're coping well under the circumstances then bang it hits you like a sledgehammer, people don't always understand how stressful the waiting is. Hopefully you will here soon. Thanx Helen if I've not heard anything by Thursday then I'm ringing the hospital, I'm back at work and that's my day.off so have all day to sort it. Hugs to all.xx
Posts.Title: Fed up, still waiting

Posts.Content: So today I have my last chemo whoop whoop. My chemo treatment 3×fec 3×t. The fec was ok other than sickness and tiredness not to bad, then I went on to the docetaxel!! Thought this wouldn't be to bad, I have a friend who's mum has just gone thro exactly the same treatment and sailed thro. Since my 1st docetaxel I have been in hospital 3 times once with neutrophinic sepsis and twice with cellulitis in the affected breast, I rattle with the amount of antibiotics ive had along with the iv antibiotics some given while admitted to hospital others daily visits to be hooked up on a drip. My last docetaxel was reduced by 30% and today's will be the same. Not worried about chemo today thrilled it's my last 1, little bit concerned that it triggers another infection but hay ho if it does it does we are well rehearsed in the signs to look for and what to do about it. Radiotherapy now been put back a couple of weeks but expected it so all good. At the end of the day we are all different some of us will sail thro, some of us will have problems along the way, but it is achievable and we will all get thro the treatment. Remember we are stronger than we think we are. Xxxx
Posts.Title: Last chemo today, what a journey!!

Posts.Content: Hi Flopsyuk,  I have had GCFS injections on both cycles of the T, and still ended up with the infections. Strange how it affects us all differently. The fec was easy for me in comparison to your experience. Xxx
Posts.Title: Last chemo today, what a journey!!

Posts.Content: Had lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node removal 28th January results not as good as hoped. Had to go back for more margin and lymph node clearance as lymph node was positive for cancer. Nobody expected this. I go back tomorrow to find out how many lymph nodes are involved. I have a grade 3 invasive ductal carcinoma HER2 positive. Trying to be positive but worried about tomorrow.  Yvonne
Posts.Title: Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hiya, I had docetaxel, my oncology nurse told me it's like marmite it either loves you or hates you. I had a few aches and pains but not to much. I did have trouble sleeping couldn't say if it was the docetaxel or the big steroid dose. I slept if i felt tired and the nights I couldn't sleep I'd watch a film or something. I had the foul taste and I drank iced water or iced squash tbh neither tasted particularly good, I ate strong cheese to try an rid the taste, mashed potatoes and cheese sauce was a firm favourite because it was soft as I ended up with a very sore mouth due to mouth ulcers, so be careful of that and use the mouthwash. Also be vigilant with your temperature I ended up with a couple of infections which came on very quickly. I'm not trying to scare you we are all different and it affects us all in different ways, some sail thro some find it tougher going but we get there in the end. X
Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) Aches & Pains!!

Posts.Content: Just had letter saying my appointment for mammogram has been changed from March to June!! The new letter says to see combined surgeons which has now got my brain working overtime. Also this is an appointment for my 1st annual mammogram 18 months after being diagnosed with breast cancer!!!! Annual to me means 12 months not 18! Just get on top of this mentality and something else happens to kick me back down!
Posts.Title: Angry! Appointment change

Posts.Content: Thanx Carolyn for the reply, original mammogram was symptomatic, I was and am to young to fall into the routine mammogram category. I don't have symptoms at the moment that I can tell, tho the breast I had treatment for is still very swollen so I probably wouldn't be able to feel any new lumps unless they were on the surface.  X
Posts.Title: Angry! Appointment change

Posts.Content: Thanks for the reply, my 1st surgery for lumpectomy and sentinel node was Jan 2016, I had further surgery for node clearance and extra margins Feb 2016. I've called  the breast unit and left a message for them to give me a call. X
Posts.Title: Angry! Appointment change

Posts.Content: Hiya, this is the right place for help and support. I had lumpectomy and only 1 node removed as needle biopsy had been clear on nodes. I ended up having to go back for more margin and another 10 nodes removed because I also didn't have clear enough margins and node taken on 1st opp showed positive for cancer, this sent me into complete panic, everything taken on second opp was clear for cancer and was told it's quite common to have to go back for further surgery. Try not to worry you are in good hands, I found staying away from Dr Google and keeping.myself occupied helped with the waiting. Xx
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply, feel a bit better about it after reading it.
Posts.Title: Told yesterday i have breast cancer

Posts.Content: I found a lump end Nov, took nearly 2weeks to get into my gp another 2 weeks for 1st hospital app had to wait another 2 weeks for mammogram and ultrasound where they did biopsy on breast and lymph node almost another 2 weeks which brings us to yesterday, feel numb scared anxious etc etc. I go for lump and sentinel limph node removal, all this waiting is so hard to deal with, is this timescale normal?
Posts.Title: Told yesterday i have breast cancer

Posts.Content: My surgery is on 28th, It had already been booked in when I had my appointment to tell me the results of  biopsy
Posts.Title: Told yesterday i have breast cancer

Posts.Content: This trial does not run in my area, I went to drs after finding a lump and have grade 3 idc, it would have been between 3/6 years before I was called for routine mammogram. I'm just thankful I found the lump and acted upon it.  Since my diagnosis I encourage my friends and family to check themselves as for some of us waiting for the routine mammogram is to late. X
Posts.Title: How to make others aware

Posts.Content: Hi Maz73, I was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma with a high grade DCIS, I was also told after surgery the node they removed was positive (macro metastasis) is what the lab report said, I went into immediate panic thinking the metastatic part ment I had secondary cancer.  I had further surgery for a node clearance which all came back as negative, I was also told the nodes had done their job and and caught the cancer before it spread to the rest of my body. I also had more margin on the second opp which was also clear, no signs of any cancer on the second surgery. I still needed chemo as mine was a Grade 3 which is an aggressive form. Is it the stage or the grade that is 3 for you? My stage was 2 even though it was in 1 node.  I was Er neg and her2 +. My diagnosis was Jan2016 I'm now back at work and enjoying life, before you know it the treatment will be behind you.  We are all stronger than we think we are, until faced with the challenge of our lives, then we see how strong we really are. Hope this helps and good luck with your treatment. X
Posts.Title: Metastatic lymph node?

Posts.Content: Everyone reacts differently to the chemo, my advice would be to drink plenty, take your temp regularly, and listen to your body, if your tired rest. I would also have an overnight bag ready while on the chemo, just in case you have to go in with a high temperature. I'm not gonna lie chemo can be tough, we all react to it differently, it is also very doable. Xx
Posts.Title: Metastatic lymph node?

Posts.Content: I've had 2 months to get used to fact I've got breast cancer, I've had 2 surgeries 11 lymph nodes removed 1 showed cancer 10 were clear and now have clear margins. Everything removed on 2nd opp (10 nodes, extra margin) was clear. I know it's HER2 + got told this ages ago so it's not like it's new information but for some reason today I've got myself worked up about the HER2 status.
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Hiya Dreamthief, Thanks for your reply. It's the worry about reoccurrence that has got me worked up, I should listen to my own advise and stay away from Dr Google, it's not like I don't know better!! Thanx for your reply I feel a lot better about things today. Thanx again xx
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Posted yesterday about results,  just out of appointment all the lymph nodesare clear extra margin clear as well, so had 11 nodes removed only 1 turned out to be cancerous am sooooo happy. Oncology appointment on 23rd.
Posts.Title: Good news on results

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your replys, the help and advice is great I'm in a much better place again.  I think it's right what's been said that if it wasn't HER2 + then I'd worry about another aspect.  I have a weekend of normality going out with friends to a show so looking forward to that. Xx
Posts.Title: Got myself worked up about HER2 + status

Posts.Content: Hi Loolyboo, I was told from the start chemo would be about 6 weeks from surgery all.my.appointments seem to be 2 weeks.apart. my next appointment is 23rd with oncologist, so don't know if your wait is normal but thought would let you know 6 weeks is standard policy for my hospital. Best wishes with your chemo. Xxx
Posts.Title: Waiting forever!

Posts.Content: Hi CEC It's all very scary to start with, we all have our ups and downs. I ended up having 2 opps 1st one lumpectomy and 1 sentinel lymph node removal, had to go back for 2nd opp as lymph node was positive and not enough clear margin on the breast tissue, this sent me into complete panic and meltdown. As it turned out everything taken on 2nd opp was clear so my meltdown turned out to be all for nothing. There are many ups and downs on this journey but we learn to cope. I'm now 2 chemo done with 4 more to go. I would try talking to your daughter again as I have found families support invaluable, I also think you may need help with you animals for some of the time, do you have friends who can help? I found staying away from dr Google helpful, this forum is by far the best for help and support. I also found keeping my mind occupied at quiet times by doing jigsaw puzzles helped me. Hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: How are you all so brave, I've just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hiya Jen72, I have worked on and off since my surgery I ended up having 2 surgeries and initially took time off after each to recover then went back to work on reduced hours and lighter work duties, my company have been great and basically I can do as much or as little as I want. I intend to apply the same principle during my chemo tho will have to be careful about infection, I am a carer so higher risk of infection tho I can do office work if I want and or the more able clients who are generally in good health so pose no more infection risk than going to see family or friends. From my point of view taking the next 6 months off which is what my oncologist suggested I do is not an option, while my company are great and supportive they don't pay sick pay and I can't live off ssp. X
Posts.Title: Work during treatment
